Hi there,

I admit,=
 I have heritrix 1.15 and 3.0, and just skipped 2.x entirely.
So, if that i=
sn't sufficiently similar, you may ignore this.

The crawler version isn't =
terribly significant, though, what you
are describing is data management,  =
applicable to pretty much
any given data app.  Crawler, or something else t=
hat produces
a lot of data in an incremental way.

Specific to how one deal=
s with heritrix:

 - I find it very useful to pause the crawler, pull out t=
he arcs and/or 
warcs
that are complete, move them out.  One gets much bett=
er disk I/O
handling when you do it this way.  (Read: it all finishes much =
faster)

- Be careful with the log files.  They are live and open, and if y=
ou
do something that looks innocuous, e.g. copy/truncate, the application
w=
ill still be confused by it, since it will have an open file handle
against=
 it.  If you are moving things via the web UI, it may take care
of some of =
this cleanly for you.  (which the cron work may not do right.)

You general=
ly can't move a file out that a program isn't done
with.  What will happen =
is:

1. The file name will disappear from the directory structure.
2. The s=
pace will not be reclaimed on the disk.
3. When it does finally exit, the f=
ile name and data content
of said file will be problematic.  It may re-appe=
ar.
Really depends on what program did what, when, but you could have a 
sp=
arse data
file, a complete data file from when you first moved it,

So, loo=
k at why you are moving log files.  If you need to do some sort
of post pro=
cessing associated with the archive data files you moved,
try a copy, with =
maintaining a pointer in the copy as to what is going
on, rather than actua=
lly moving logs, until the crawl exits.
Then do a final cleanup.

John
